title: Essential String Methods
description: Most commonly used string manipulation methods.

cards.front: How do you convert a string to uppercase?
cards.back: Use the upper() method: 'hello'.upper() returns 'HELLO'

cards.front: How do you remove whitespace from both ends of a string?
cards.back: Use the strip() method: '  hello  '.strip() returns 'hello'

cards.front: How do you split a string into a list?
cards.back: Use the split() method: 'hello world'.split() returns ['hello', 'world']

cards.front: How do you replace text in a string?
cards.back: Use the replace() method: 'hello world'.replace('world', 'Python') returns 'hello Python'

cards.front: How do you check if a string starts with specific text?
cards.back: Use the startswith() method: 'Python'.startswith('Py') returns True

cards.front: How do you convert a string to lowercase?
cards.back: Use the lower() method: 'HELLO'.lower() returns 'hello'

cards.front: How do you get the length of a string?
cards.back: Use the len() function: len('hello') returns 5

cards.front: How do you check if a string contains a substring?
cards.back: Use the 'in' operator: 'world' in 'hello world' returns True
Use + operator: 'hello' + ' ' + 'world' or 'hello {}'.format('world')

cards.front: How do you repeat a string?
cards.back: Use * operator: 'hello' * 3 returns 'hellohellohello'

cards.front: How do you access individual characters?
cards.back: Use indexing: 'hello'[0] returns 'h'

cards.front: How do you get the last character?
cards.back: Use negative indexing: 'hello'[-1] returns 'o'

title: String Testing Methods
description: Methods to check string properties and content.

cards.back: Returns True if all characters are digits: '123'.isdigit() returns True
Returns True if all characters are letters: 'hello'.isalpha() returns True
Returns True if all characters are letters or digits: 'hello123'.isalnum() returns True
Returns True if all letters are lowercase: 'hello'.islower() returns True
Returns True if all letters are uppercase: 'HELLO'.isupper() returns True
Returns True if all characters are whitespace: '   '.isspace() returns True
Returns True if string is titlecased: 'Hello World'.istitle() returns True
Checks if string starts with specified prefix: 'hello'.startswith('he') returns True
Checks if string ends with specified suffix: 'hello'.endswith('lo') returns True
Returns True if string is a valid Python identifier: 'variable'.isidentifier() returns True
Returns True if all characters are printable: 'hello\n'.isprintable() returns False
Returns True if all characters are ASCII: 'hello'.isascii() returns True

title: String Transformation Methods
description: Methods to change case and format of strings.

cards.back: Capitalizes first character, lowercases rest: 'hello world'.capitalize() returns 'Hello world'
Capitalizes first letter of each word: 'hello world'.title() returns 'Hello World'
Swaps case of all characters: 'Hello'.swapcase() returns 'hELLO'
Converts to lowercase for caseless comparison: more aggressive than lower()
Centers string in field of given width: 'hello'.center(10) returns '  hello   '
Left-justifies string in field: 'hello'.ljust(10) returns 'hello     '
Right-justifies string in field: 'hello'.rjust(10) returns '     hello'
Pads string with zeros on left: '42'.zfill(5) returns '00042'
Replaces tabs with spaces: 'hello\tworld'.expandtabs(4) replaces tab with 4 spaces
Applies translation table to string: useful for character replacement

title: String Searching and Finding
description: Methods to locate and work with substrings.

cards.back: Returns lowest index of substring: 'hello world'.find('world') returns 6
Returns highest index of substring: 'hello world world'.rfind('world') returns 12
Like find() but raises ValueError if not found: 'hello'.index('x') raises error
Like rfind() but raises ValueError if not found
Counts non-overlapping occurrences: 'hello hello'.count('hello') returns 2
Splits at first occurrence: 'hello world'.partition(' ') returns ('hello', ' ', 'world')
Splits at last occurrence: 'hello world test'.rpartition(' ') returns ('hello world', ' ', 'test')
Splits on line breaks: 'hello\nworld'.splitlines() returns ['hello', 'world']
Creates translation table for translate(): str.maketrans('aeiou', '12345')
Encodes string to bytes: 'hello'.encode('utf-8') returns b'hello'

title: String Splitting and Joining
description: Methods to split strings and join sequences.

cards.back: Splits string by separator: 'hello world'.split() returns ['hello', 'world']

cards.front: What does split() use as default separator?
cards.back: Any whitespace (spaces, tabs, newlines)

cards.front: How do you split on specific character?
cards.back: 'a,b,c'.split(',') returns ['a', 'b', 'c']
Splits from right: 'a b c d'.rsplit(' ', 2) returns ['a b', 'c', 'd']
Joins sequence with string as separator: ' '.join(['hello', 'world']) returns 'hello world'

cards.front: How do you join without separator?
cards.back: ''.join(['hello', 'world']) returns 'helloworld'
Splits on line boundaries: 'hello\nworld\ntest'.splitlines() returns ['hello', 'world', 'test']

cards.front: How do you split and keep separator?
cards.back: Use re.split() with capturing groups for regex-based splitting
Limits number of splits: 'a b c d'.split(' ', 2) returns ['a', 'b', 'c d']

cards.front: How do you split on multiple delimiters?
cards.back: Use re.split() or chain split() calls: 'a,b;c'.replace(',', ';').split(';')

title: String Formatting
description: Methods and techniques for string formatting.

cards.back: Formats string with placeholders: 'Hello {}'.format('world') returns 'Hello world'

cards.front: How do you use positional arguments?
cards.back: '{0} {1}'.format('hello', 'world') returns 'hello world'

cards.front: How do you use keyword arguments?
cards.back: '{name} is {age}'.format(name='Alice', age=25)
Literal string interpolation: f'Hello {name}' (Python 3.6+)

cards.front: How do you format numbers in f-strings?
cards.back: f'Value: {pi:.2f}' formats pi to 2 decimal places
Old-style formatting: 'Hello %s' % 'world' returns 'Hello world'

cards.front: How do you format dates in strings?
cards.back: Use datetime.strftime(): datetime.now().strftime('%Y-%m-%d')

cards.front: What does lstrip() and rstrip() do?
cards.back: lstrip() removes leading whitespace, rstrip() removes trailing whitespace

cards.front: How do you strip specific characters?
cards.back: 'hello'.strip('lo') removes 'l','o' from ends: returns 'hel'
Removes prefix if present: 'hello world'.removeprefix('hello ') returns 'world'
Removes suffix if present: 'hello.txt'.removesuffix('.txt') returns 'hello'

cards.front: How do you pad strings with specific character?
cards.back: 'hello'.ljust(10, '*') returns 'hello*****'
string[start:end:step] - extracts substring with optional step

cards.front: How do you reverse a string?
cards.back: 'hello'[::-1] returns 'olleh'

cards.front: How do you get every other character?
cards.back: 'hello'[::2] returns 'hlo'
Reverses direction: 'hello'[3:0:-1] returns 'lle'

cards.front: How do you check if string is palindrome?
cards.back: string == string[::-1]
Creates a copy of the string

cards.front: How do you extract domain from email?
cards.back: 'user@example.com'.split('@')[1] or 'user@example.com'.partition('@')[2]
Creates shallow copy (same as string[::])

cards.front: How do you get string length without len()?
cards.back: sum(1 for _ in string) - but len() is better!
Python caches short strings for memory efficiency

title: Unicode and Encoding
description: Working with Unicode strings and encoding.

cards.back: Universal character encoding standard supporting all writing systems
Converts string to bytes: 'hello'.encode('utf-8')
Converts bytes to string: b'hello'.decode('utf-8')
Variable-length encoding for Unicode, backward compatible with ASCII

cards.front: How do you handle encoding errors?
cards.back: 'text'.encode('ascii', errors='ignore') ignores unencodable characters
Returns Unicode code point: ord('A') returns 65
Returns character from code point: chr(65) returns 'A'
Unique number assigned to each Unicode character
import unicodedata; unicodedata.normalize('NFC', text)
__str__() for users, __repr__() for developers/debugging

title: String Performance and Best Practices
description: Efficient string handling and best practices.

cards.back: Allows string interning and thread safety, prevents accidental modification

cards.front: How do you efficiently build strings?
cards.back: Use ''.join(list_of_strings) instead of += in loops

cards.front: Why is join() better than + for concatenation?
cards.back: + creates new string each time, join() calculates total size first

cards.front: When should you use f-strings vs format()?
cards.back: f-strings for readability, format() when template is dynamic

cards.front: How do you avoid string concatenation in loops?
cards.back: Use list comprehension then join: ''.join(str(x) for x in items)
Python reuses identical string objects to save memory
Literals, identifiers, compile-time constants, strings with only ASCII letters/digits/underscores

cards.front: How do you force string interning?
cards.back: sys.intern(string) - useful for dictionary keys

cards.front: What is the cost of string operations?
cards.back: Creation is expensive, but comparison and slicing are fast

cards.front: How do you check string equality efficiently?
cards.back: Python optimizes string comparison by length and content

cards.front: How do you parse CSV data?
cards.back: Use csv module: csv.reader() handles quotes and escaping

cards.front: How do you clean user input?
cards.back: input.strip().lower() - normalize whitespace and case

cards.front: How do you extract numbers from text?
cards.back: Use regular expressions: re.findall(r'\d+', text)

cards.front: How do you format file paths?
cards.back: Use os.path.join() or pathlib.Path for cross-platform compatibility

cards.front: How do you create slugs for URLs?
cards.back: text.lower().replace(' ', '-').replace('_', '-') - simple slugification

cards.front: How do you validate email format?
cards.back: '@' in email and '.' in email.split('@')[1] - basic validation
import string; text.translate(str.maketrans('', '', string.punctuation))

cards.front: How do you count words in text?
cards.back: len(text.split()) - simple word count

cards.front: How do you find most common words?
cards.back: from collections import Counter; Counter(text.lower().split()).most_common(10)

cards.front: How do you generate random strings?
cards.back: import random, string; ''.join(random.choices(string.ascii_letters, k=10))
